editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

keywords.term: Edward, -- I, -- King of England, -- 1239-1307 -- Drama -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: The famous chronicle of King Edward the first, surnamed Edward Longshanks, with his return from the holy land.
Also the life of Llevellen rebel in Wales.
Lastly, the sinking of Queen Elinor, who sunk at Charing-cross, and rose again at Pottershith, now named Queenehith.
London printed by Abel Jeffes, and are to be sold by William barley, at his shop in gracious street 1593.

div.head: The famous chronicle history of King Edward the first, surnamed Edward Longshanks: with the sincking of Queen Elinor at Charing-cross, and her rising again at potter's heath, otherwise called Queen heath.
div.stage: Enter Gilbart de Clare Earl of Glocester, with the Earl of Sussex, Mortimer the Earl of march, David Lluellen's brother, waiting on Helinor the Queen mother.

sp.speaker: The Queen mother.
sp.l: My l. lieutenant of Glocester, and L. Mortimor,
To do you honour in your sovereign's eyes,
That as we hear is newly come a-land,
From Palestine, with all his men of war.
The poor remainder of the royal fleet,
Preserved by miracle in Sicill road.
Go mount your coursers, meet him on the way,
Pray him to spur his steed, minutes and hours,
Until his mother see her princely son,
Shining in glory of his safe return.

sp.speaker: Manet Queen mother.
sp.l: Illustrious England, ancient feat of Kings,
Whose chivalry hath royalized thy fame:
That sounding bravely through terrestrial veil,
Proclaiming conquests, spoils, and victories,
Rings glorious echoes through the farthest world.
What warlike nation trained in feats of arms,
what barbarous people, stubborn or untamed,
What climate under the meridian signs,
Or frozen zone under his brumal stage,
Erst have not quaked and trembled at the name
Of Britain, and her mighty conqueror,?
Her neighbour realms as Scotland, Denmark, France,
Aude with their deeds, and jealous of her arms,
Have begged defensive and offensive leagues.
Thus Europe rich and mighty in her Kings,
Hath feared brave England dreadful in her Kings:
And now to eternize Albion's champions,
Equivalent with troyans' ancient fame,
Comes lovely Edward from Jerusalem,
Veering before the wind, ploughing the sea,
His stretched sails filled with the breath of men,
That through the world admires his manliness.
And loe at last, arrived in Dover road,
Long shank your King, your glory and our son,
With troops of conquering lords and warlike knights,
Like bloody crested Mars o'erlooks his host,
Higher than all his army by the head,
Marching along as bright as Phoebus eyes,
And we his mother shall behold our son,
And England's peers shall see their sovereign.
sp.stage: The trumpets sound, and enter the train, viz. his maimed soldiers with headpieces and garlands on them, every man with his red cross on his coat: the ancient born in a chair, his garland and his plumes on his headpiece, his ensign in his hand. Enter after them Glocester and Mortimer bareheaded, and others as many as may be. Then Longshanks and his wife Elinor, Edmund Couchback, and Jone and signior Moumfort the Earl of Leicester's prisoner, with sailors and soldiers, and Charles de Moumfort his brother.

sp.speaker: Q. mother.
sp.l: Glocester, Edward, oh my sweet sons.
sp.stage: And then she falls and sounds.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Help ladies: oh ingrateful destiny,
To welcome Edward with this tragedy.

sp.speaker: Glocest.
sp.l: Patient your highness, 'tis but mother's love,
Received with sight of her thrice valiant sons:
Madam amaze not, see his majesty
Returned with glory from the holy land.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Brave sons the worthy champions of our god,
The honourable soldiers of the highest,
Bear with your mother whose abundant love,
With tears of joys salutes your sweet return,
From famous journeys hard and fortunate.
But lords alas how heavy is our loss,
Since your departure to these Christian wars,
The King your father, and the prince your son,
And your brave uncle Almains emperor,
Ay me are dead.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Take comfort madam, leave these sad laments,
Dear was my uncle, dearer was my son:
And ten times dearer was my noble father,
Yet were their lives valued at thousand worlds,
They cannot scape the arrest of dreadful death:
Death that doth seize and summon all alike.
Then leaving them to heavenly blessedness,
To join in thrones of glory with the just,
I do salute your royal majesty.
My gracious mother Queen, and you my lords,
Gilbart de Clare, Sussex, and Mortimer,
And all the princely states of England's peers,
With health and honour to your heart's content,
And welcome wished England on whose ground,
These feet so often have desired to tread,
Welcome sweet Queen my fellow traveller,
Welcome sweet Nell my fellow mate in arms,
Whose eyes have seen the slaughtered Sarazens,
Piled in the ditches of Jerusalem,
And lastly welcome manly followers,
That bears the scars of honour and of arms,
and on your war drums carry crowns as Kings,
Crown mural, naval, and triumphant all,
At view of whom the Turks have trembling fled,
And Sarazens like sheep before the walls,
Have made their cottages in walled towns,
But bulwarks had no ●ence to beat you back,
Lords, these and they will enter brazen gates,
And tear down lime and mortar with their nails.
Embrace them barons these have got the name,
Of English gentlemen and knights at arms:
Not one of these but in the champain field,
Hath won his crown, his collar and his spurs,
Not Caesar loading through the streets of Rome,
The captive Kings of conquered nations,
Was in his princely triumphs honoured more,
Than English Edward in this martial sight.
〈◊〉 your lives are lost in service of the lord,
Which is your glory and your country's fame,
For li●s, you shalt have ●ing, lordships, lands,
And be my counsellors in wars affairs:
Soldiers sit down, Nell sit thee by my side,
These be prince Edward's pompious treasury.
sp.stage: The Queen mother being set on the one side, and Queen Elinor on the other, the King sitteth in the midst mounted highest, and at his feet the ensign underneath him.
sp.l: O glorious Capitol, beauteous senate house,
Triumphant Edward, how like sturdy oaks,
Do these thy soldiers circle thee about,
To shield and shelter thee from winter's storms?
Display thy cross, old aims of the vies,
Dub on your drums tanned with India's sun,
My lusty western lads, matreveirs thou,
Sound proudly here a perfect point of war,
In honour of thy sovereign's safe return.
Thus long shanks bids his soldiers bien veneu.
sp.stage: Use drums, trumpets, and ensigns, and then speak Edward.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: O God my God, the brightness of my day,
How oft hast thou preserved thy servant safe,
By sea and land, yea in the gates of death,
Oh God to thee how highly am I bound,
For setting me with these on English ground:
One of my mansion houses will I give,
To be a college for my maimed men,
Where every one shall have an hundred marks
Of yearly pension to his maintenance,
A soldier that for Christ and country sights,
Shall want no living whilst King Edward lives,
Lords you that love me now be liberal,
And give your largesse to these maimed men.

sp.speaker: Q. Mot.
sp.l: Towards this erection doth thy mother give,
Out of her dowry, five thousand pounds of gold,
To find them surgeons to recure their wounds,
And whilst this ancient standard bearer lives,
He shall have forty pound of yearly fee,
And be my beadsman father if you please.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Madam I tell you England never bred,
A better soldier than your beadsman is,
And that the sultan and his army felt.

sp.speaker: Edmund.
sp.l: Out of the duchy of rich Lancaster,
To find soft bedding for their bruised bones,
Duke Edmund gives three thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Gramercies brother Edmund,
Happy is England under Edward's reign,
When men are had so highly in regard,
That nobles strive who shall remunerate,
The soldier's resolution with regard.
My lord of Glocester what is your benevolence?

sp.speaker: Glocest.
sp.l: A thousand marks and please your majesty.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: And yours my lord of Sussex?

sp.speaker: Sussex.
sp.l: Five hundred pound, and please your majesty.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: What say you sir David of Brecknock.

sp.speaker: David
sp.l: To a soldier sir David cannot be too liberal,
Yet that I may give no more than a poor knight is able
And not presume as a mighty Earl,
I give my lord four hundred, four score,
And nineteen pounds:
And so my lord of Sussex I am behind you an ace.

sp.speaker: Sussex.
sp.l: And yet sir David ye amble after apace.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Well said dam. thou couldst not be a Camber Britain
If thou didst not love a soldier with thy heart,
Let me see how is my arithmetic wil serve,
To total the particulars.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Why my lord I hope you mean,
I shall be a benefactor to my fellow soldiers.

sp.speaker: Longshanks.
sp.l: And well said Nell.
What wilt thou I set down for thee?

sp.speaker: Q. El.
sp.l: Nay, my lord I am of age to set it down for myself.
You will allow what I do, will you not?

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: That I will madam,
Were it to the value of my kingdom.

sp.speaker: Qu. Elin.
sp.l: What is the sum my lord?

sp.speaker: Longshanks.
sp.l: 10000 pounds my Nell.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.p: Then Elinor bethink thee of a gift worthy the King of England's wife, and the King of Spain's daughter, and give such a largesse, that the chronicles of this land may crake with record of thy liberality.
sp.l: There my lord, neither one, two, nor three,
But a poor cipher in agrum, to enrich good fellows,
And compound their figure in their kind.

sp.speaker: Longsh
sp.l: Madam I commend your composition,
An argument of your honourable disposition:
Sweet Nell thou shouldst not be thyself,
Did not with thy mounting mind,
Thy gift surmount the rest.

sp.speaker: Gloce.
sp.l: Call you this ridiculus mus? marry sir this mouse
would make a foul hole in a fair cheese,
'Tis but a cipher in agrum,
And it hath made of 10000 pounds, 100000 pounds:

sp.speaker: Edmund.
sp.l: A princely gift and worthy memory.

sp.speaker: Clocester.
sp.l: My gracious lord, as erst I was assigned,
Lieutenant to his majesty,
Here render I up the crown left in charge with me,
By your princely father King Henry,
Who on his death bed still did call for you,
And dying, wild to you the diadem.

sp.speaker: Longshanks.
sp.l: Thanks worthy lords,
And seeing by doom of heavens it is decreed,
And lawful line of our succession,
Unworthy Edward is become your King,
We take it as a blessing from on high,
And will our coronation be solemnised,
Upon the 14. of December next.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Upon the 14. of December next?
Alas my lord, the time is all too short
And sudden, for so great solemnity:
A year were scarce enough to set a work,
Tailors embroiderers, and men of rare device,
For preparation of so great estate.
Trust me sweet Ned, hardly shall I bethink me,
In twenty weeks what fashion robes to wear,
I pray thee then defer it till the spring,
That we may have our garments point device.
I mean to send for tailors into Spain,
That shall confer of some fantastic suits,
With those that be our cunning'st Englishmen,
What? let me brave it now or never Ned.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Madam content ye, would that were greatest care
You shall have garments to your heart's desire,
I never read but Englishmen excelled,
For change of rare devises every way.

sp.speaker: Q. Eli.
sp.l: Yet pray thee Ned, my love, my lord, and King,
My fellow soldier, and compeer in arms,
do so much honour to thy Elinor,
To wear a suit that thee shall give thy grace,
Of he one cost and workmanship perhaps.

sp.speaker: Q. Mot.
sp.l: 'Twill come by leasurs daughter than I fear,
Thou'rt too fine finger to be quick at work.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Twixt us a greater matter breaks no square,
So it be such my Nell as may beseem ,
The majesty and greatness of a King.
And now my lords and loving friends,
Follow your general to the court,
After his travels to repose him then,
There to recount with pleasure what is past,
Of wars alarms, showers and sharpest storms.
sp.stage: Exeunt all, saving the Queen and her daughter.

sp.speaker: Q. Eli.
sp.l: Now Elinor, now England's lovely Queen,
Bethink thee of the greatness of thy state:
And how to bear thyself with royalty,
Above the other Queens of Christendom,
That Spain reaping renown by Elinor,
And Elinor adding renown to Spain,
Britain may her magnificence admire,
I tell thee Joan, what time our highness sits,
Under our royal canopy of state,
Glistering with pendants of the purest gold,
Like as our seat were spangled all with stars
The world shall wonder at our majesty,
As if the daughter of eternal Ops,
Turned to the likeness of vermilion fumes,
Where from her cloudy womb the centaurs leaped.
Were in her royal seat enthronized.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Madam, if Joan thy daughter may advise,
Let not your honour make your manners change
The people of this land are men of war,
The women courteous, mild, and debonair,
Laying their lives at princes' feet,
That governs with familiar majesty,
But if their sovereigns once 'gin swell with pride,
disdaning commons love which is the strength,
And sureness of the richest common wealth:
That prince were better live a private life,
Then rule with tyranny and discontent.

sp.speaker: Q. Eli.
sp.l: Indeed we count them headstrong Englishmen
But we shall hold them in a Spanish yoke:
And make them know their lord and sovereign.
Come daughter let us home for to provide:
For all the cunning workmen of this I'll,
In our great chamber shall be set a work,
And in my hall shall bountifully feed.
My King like Phoebus bridegroom like shall march
With lovely Xheeis to her grassy bed,
And all the lookers on shall stand amazed,
To see King Edward and his lovely Queen,
Sit lovely in England's stately throne.
sp.stage: Enter Lluellen, alias prince of Wales: Rice ap Meredeth, Owen ap Rice, with swords and bucklers and freeze jerkins.

sp.speaker: Llu.
sp.l: Come rice and rouse thee for thy countries good,
Follow the man that means to make you great:
Follow Lluellen rightful prince of Wales.
Sprung from the loins of great Cadwallader,
Descended from the loins of Trojan Brute,
And though the traitorous 'Saxons, Normans, Danes,
Have sp●t the true Romans of glorious Troy,
Within the western mountains of this I'll,
Yet have we hope to climb these stony pales,
When Londoners as Romans erst amazed,
Shall trembling cry Lluellen's at the gate.
T'accomplish this, thus have I brought you forth,
Disguised to Milford haven, here attend,
The landing of the lady Aeliner.
Her stay doth make me muse, the wind stands fair
and ten days hence we did expect them here,
Neptune be favourable to my love,
And steer her keel with thy three forked mace,
That from this shore I may behold her sails,
And in mine arms embrace my dearest dear.

sp.speaker: Rice.
sp.l: Brave prince of Wales, this honourable match,
Cannot but turn to Cambria's common good.
Simon de Momfort, her thrice valiant son,
That in the baron's wars was general,
Was loved and honoured of the Englishmen.
When they shall hear, she's your espoused wife.
Assure your grace we shall have great supply,
To make our roads in England mightily.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.l: What we resolved, must strongly be performed,
Before the King return from Palestine,
While he wins glory at Jerusalem,
Let us win ground upon the Englishmen.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Owen ap Rice, 'tis that Lluellen fears,
I fear me Edward will be come a shore,
Ere we can make provision for the war.
But be it as it will, within his court
My brother David is, that bears a face,
As if he were my greatest enemy,
He by this craft shall creep into her heart,
And give intelligence from time to time,
Of her intentions, drifts and stratagems.
Here let us rest upon the salt sea shore,
And while our eyes long for our hearts desires,
Let us like friend's pastime us on the sands,
Our frolic minds are ominous for good.
sp.stage: Enter friar Hugh ap David, Guenthian his wench in flannel, and Jack his novice.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Gwenthian as I am true man,
So will I do the best I can:
Gwenthian as I am true priest,
so will I be at thy behest:
Gwenthian as I am true friar,
So will I be at thy desire.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.l: My master stands too near the fire,
Trust him not wench, he will prove a liar.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: True man, true friar, true priest, and true knave,
These four in one this trull shall have,

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Here swear I by my shaven crown,
Wench if I give thee a gay green gown,
I'll take thee up as I laid thee down,
And never bruise nor batter thee.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.l: O swear not master, flesh is frail,
Wench when the sign is in the tail,
Mighty is love and will prevail,
This churchman doth but flatter thee.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: A pretty worm, and a lusty friar,
Made for the field, not for the choir.

sp.speaker: Guenth.
sp.l: Mas. friar as I am true maid,
So do I hold me well a paid:
'Tis churchman's lay and verity,
To live in love and charity,
And therefore ween I as my creed,
Your words shall company my deed,
Davie my dear, I yield in all,
Thine own to go and come at call.

sp.speaker: Rice.
sp.l: And so far forth begins our brawl.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Then my Gwenthian to begin,
Sith idleness in love is sin,
Boy to the town I will thee hie,
And so return even by and by,
When thou with cakes and muskadine,
And other junkets good and fine,
Hast filled thy bottle and thy bag.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.l: Now master as I am true wag,
I will be neither late nor lag,
But go and come with gossip's cheer,
Ere Gib our cat can lick her care.
For long ago I learned in school,
That lover's desire, and pleasures cool:
Sanct Ceres' sweets and Bacchus' vine,
Now master for the cakes and wine.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Wench to pass away the time in glee,
Gwenthian set thee down by me,
And let our lips and voices meet,
In a merry country song.

sp.speaker: Guenth.
sp.l: Friar, I am at beek and bay,
And at thy commandment to sing and say,
And other sports among.

sp.speaker: Ow.
sp.l: I marry my lord, this is somewhat like a man's money,
Here's a wholesome Welsh wench,
Leapt in her flannel as warm as wool,
And as fit as a pudding for a friar's mouth.
sp.stage: The friar and Guenthian sing: Lluellen speaks to them.
sp.l: Pax vobis, pax vobis, good fellows fair fall ye.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Et cum spiritu tuo.
Friend's have you any thing else to say to the friar?

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.l: Much good do you, much good you,
My master's heart elie.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: And you sir when ye eat:
Have ye any thing else to say to the friar?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Nothing, but I would gladly know,
If 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 be your first dish, what shall be your last service.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 ●y be sir I count it physic,
To feed but on one dish at a sitting:
Sir would you any thing else with the friar?

sp.speaker: Rice.
sp.l: O nothing sir, but if you had any manners,
You might bid us fall too.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Nay and that be the matter good enough,
Is this all ye have to say to the friar?

sp.speaker: Lluel
sp.l: All we have to say to you sir, it may be sir,
We would walk aside with your wench a little.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: My masters and friends, I am a poor friar, a man of god's making, and a good fellow as you are, legs, feet, face and hands, and heart from top to toe, of my word, right shape and Christendom: and I love a wench as a wench should be loved, and if you love yourself walk good friends I pray you, and let the friar alone with his flesh.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.p: O friar, your holy mother the church teaches you to abstain from these morsels, therefore my masters 'tis a deed of charity to remove this stumbling block, a fair wench, a shrewd temptation to a friar's conscience.

sp.speaker: Guen.
sp.p: Friend if you knew the friar half so well as the bailie of Brecknock, you would think you might as so one move monk Davie into the sea, as Guenth. from his side.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Mas by your leave, we'll prove.

sp.speaker: Guenth.
sp.l: At your peril if you move his patience.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Brother, brother, and my good countrymen.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.p: Countrymen? nay I cannot think that an English friar, will come so far into Wales barefooted.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.p: That's more than you know, and yet my lord he might ride, having a filly so near. Warnings:

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Hands off good countryman, at few words and fair

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Countrymen, not so sir, we renounce thee friar, and refuse your country.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Then brother and my good friends,
Hands off and if you love your ease.

sp.speaker: Rice.
sp.l: Ease me no easings, we'll ease you of this carriage.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Fellow be gone quickly, or my pike staff and I will set thee away with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Llu.
sp.l: I am sorry trust me to see the church so unpatient.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Ye dogs ounes, do me a shroud turn and mock me too, flesh and blood will not bear this: then rise up Robert and say to Richard, red rationem villicationistuae. sir countryman, kinsman, Englishman, Welshman, you with the wench, return your habeas corpus, here's a circiorari for your procedendo.

sp.speaker: Owen.
sp.l: Hold friar we are thy countrymen.
Rice. Paid, paid, Digone, we are thy countrymen, Mundue.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: My countrymen? nay marry sir shall you not be my countrymen, you sir, you, specially you sir that refuse the friar, and renounce his country.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.p: Friar, hold thy hands, I swear as I am a gentleman, I am a Welshman, and so are the rest of honesty.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Of honesty sayest thou?
They are neither gentlemen nor Welshmen,
That will deny their country: come hither wench,
I'll have about with them once more,
For denying of their country.
sp.stage: Make as if ye would fight.

sp.speaker: Rice.
sp.l: Friar thou wottest not what thou say est,
This is the prince, and we are all his train:
Disposed to be pleasant with thee a little,
But I perceive friar, thy nose will bide no rest.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: As much as you will with me sir,
But not at any hand with my wench,
I and Richard my man here.
For here, contra omnes gentes.
But is this Lluellen the great Camber Britain?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: It is he friar, give me thy hand,
And gramercies twenty times,
I promise thee thou hast cudgeled
Two as good lessons into my jacket,
As ever churchman did at so short warning.
The one is, not to be too busy with another man's cattle,
The other, not in haste to deny my country.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: 'Tis pity my lord,
But you should have more of this learning
You profit so well by it.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.p: 'Tis pity friar but thou shouldst be Lluellen's chaplain, thou edifiest so well, and so shalt thou be, of mine honour, here I entertain thee, thy boy, and thy trull, to follow my fortune, in secula seculorum.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: And Richard my man sir and you love me,
He that stands by me, and shrunk not at all weathers,
And than you have me in my colours.

sp.speaker: Lluel
sp.l: Friars agreed: rice welcome the ruffians.
sp.stage: Enter the harper, and sing to the tune of who list to lead a soldier's life.

sp.l: Go too, go too, you britain's all,
And play the men both great and small,
A wondrous matter hath be fall,
That makes the prophet's cry and call,
Tum da et di te de te dum,
That you must march both all and some,
Against your foes with trump and drum:
I speak to you from God that you shall overcome.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: What now, who have we here?
Tum date dite dote dum.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: What have we a fellow dropped out of the element,
What's he for a man?

sp.speaker: Rice ap Mer.
sp.l: Knowest thou this Goscup?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: What? not Morgan Pigot, our good Welsh prophet,
Oh 'tis a holy harper.

sp.speaker: Meredith.
sp.l: A prophet with a murrain,
Good my lord, let's hear a few of his lines I pray you.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.l: My lords, 'tis an odd fellow I can tell you,
As any is in all Wales:
He can sing rhyme with reason, and rhyme without reason,
And without reason or rhyme.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: The devil he can,
Rhyme with reason, and rhyme without reason,
And reason without rhyme:
Then good Morgan Pigot, pluck out thy spigot,
And draw us a fresh pot,
From the kinder kind of thy knowledge.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Knowledge my son, knowledge I warranty,
How sayest thou Morgan, art thou not a very prophet?

sp.speaker: Harper.
sp.l: Friar, friar, a prophet verily,
For great Lluellen's love,
sent from above, to bring him victory.

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.p: Come then gentle prophet, let's see how thou canst salute thy prince, say, shall we have good success in our enterprise or no?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: When the weathercock of Carmarthen steeple
Shall engender young ones in the belfry,
And a herd of goats leave their pasture,
To be clothed in silver:
Then shall Brute be born a new,
And Wales record their ancient hue,
Ask friar David if this be not true.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: This my lord a means by you,
Oh he is a prophet, a prophet.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Soft you now good Morgan Pigot,
And take us with ye a little I pray,
What means your wisdom by all this.

sp.speaker: Harper.
sp.p: The weathercock (My lord) was your father, who by foul weather of waire, was driven to take sanctuary in saint Mary's at Carnarvon, where he begat young ones on your mother in the belfry, viz. your worship, and your brother David

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: But what didst thou mean by the goats?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.p: The goats that leave the pasture to be clothed in silver, are the silver goats your men wore on their sleeves.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: O how I love thee Morgan Pigot our sweet prophet.

sp.speaker: Llu.
sp.l: Hence rogue with your prophecies, out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.p: Nay good my lord, let's have a few more of these meeters, he hath great store in his head.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.l: Yea, and of the best in the market,
And your lordship would vouchsafe to hear them.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Villain away, I'll here no more of your prophecies.

sp.speaker: Harper.
sp.l: When legs shall lose their length,
Returning weary home. from out the holy land:
A Welshman shall be King,
And govern merry England.

sp.speaker: Mered
sp.l: Did I not tell your lordship he would hit it home anon?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: My lord he comes to your time that's flat.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.l: I master and you mark him, he hit the mark pat.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: As how Jack?

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.l: Why thus: when legs shall lose their length,
And thanks yield up their strength:
Returning weary home from out the holy land,
A Welshman shall be King,
And govern merry England.
sp.p: Why my lord. in this prophesy, is your advancement as plainly seen, as a three halfpence through a dish of butter in a sunny date.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I think so lack for he that sees three halfpence, must tarry till the butter be melted in the sun, and so forth apply boy

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.l: Nonego master, do you and you dare.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.p: And ●o boy thou meanest, he that tarries this prophesy, may see long shanks shorter by the head, and Lluellan wear the crown in the field.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: By lady my lord you go near the matter,
But what saith Morgan Pigot more?

sp.speaker: Harper.
sp.p: In the year of our lord God 1272, shall spring from the loins of Brute. one whose wife's name being the perfect end of his ground, shall consummate the peace betwixt England and Wales, and be advanced to ride through Cheapside with a crown on his head, and that's meant by your lordship, for your wife's name being Ellen, and your own Lluellan, beareth the perfect end of your own name: so must it needs be, that for a time Ellen flee from Lluellen, ye being betrothed in heart each to others, must needs be advanced to be highest of your kin.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Jack, I make him thy prisoner,
Look what way my fortune inclines,
That way goes he,

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.l: Sirrah, see you run swiftest.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Farewell, be far from the spigot,

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.p: Now sir, if our country ale, were as good as your metheglin, I would teach you to play the knave. or you should teach me to play the harper.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Ambo, boy, you are too light witted,
As I am light minded.

sp.speaker: Novice
sp.l: It seemed to me thou art fittest, and passing well.
sp.stage: Enter Guenther to Lluellen with letters.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: What tidings bringeth Guenther with his haste?
Say man, what bodes thy message good or bad.

sp.speaker: Guenther.
sp.l: Bad my lord, and all in vain I wot,
Thou darest thine eyes upon the wallowing main,
As erst did Aegen to behold his son,
To welcome and receive thy welcome love,
And sable sails he saw, and so mayst thou,
For whose mishap the brackish seas lament,
Edward, o Edward.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: And what of him?

sp.speaker: Guenther.
sp.l: Landed he is at Dover with his men,
From Palestine safe by his English lords,
Received in triumphs like an earthly God,
He lives to wear his father's diadem,
And sway the sword of British Albion.
But Elinor, thy Elinor.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: And what of her?
Hath amorous Neptune gazed upon my love,
And stopped her passage with his forked mace:
Or that I rather fear, oh deadly fear,
Enamoured Nereus doth he withhold my Elinor?

sp.speaker: Guenther.
sp.l: Nor neptune, Nereus nor other God,
Withholdeth from my gracious lord his love,
But cruel Edward that injurious King,
Withholds thy liefest lovely Elmor,
taking in a pinnace on the narrow seas,
By four tall ships of Bristol, and with her,
Lord Emerick her unhappy noble brother,
As from mont Argis hitherward they sailed:
This say in brief these letters tell at large.
sp.stage: Lluellen reads his brother David's letters.

sp.speaker: Lluel
sp.l: Is Longshanks then, so lusty now become,
Is my fair love my beauteous Elinor ta'en?
Villain damned villains not to guard her safe,
Or fence her sacred person from her foes,
Sun couldst thou shine and see my love beset,
And didst not clothe thy clouds in fiery coats,
O'er all the heavens with winged sulphur flames,
As when the beams like mounted combatants,
Battled with Pyetion in the fallowed lays,
But if kind Cambria deign me good aspect,
To make me chiefest brute of western Wales,
I'll short that gain-legged longshank by the top,
And make his flesh my murdering falchion's food:
To arms true britain's sprung of Trojans seed.
And with your swords write in the book of time,
Your British names in characters of blood.
Owen ap Rice, while we stay for further force,
Prepare away in post, and take with thee,
A hundred chosen of thy countrymen,
And scour the marches with your Welshmens hooks,
That Englishmen may think the Devil is come.
Rice shall remain with me, make thou thy bode,
In resolution to revenge these wrongs,
With blood of thousands guiltless of this rage,
Fly thou on them amain: Edward, my love
Be thy life's bane. Follow me countrymen,
Words make no way, my Elinor is surprised,
Robbed am I of the comfort of my life,
And know I this and am not venged on him?
sp.stage: Exit Lluellen, and the other lords.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Come boy we must buckle I see,
The prince is of my profession right:
Rather than he will lose his wench,
He will fight ab ovo usque ad mala.

sp.speaker: Novice.
sp.p: O master doubt you not but your novice will prove a hot shot, with a bottle of Metheglin.
sp.stage: Exeunt, ere the wench fall into a Welsh song, and the friar answer, and the N●u between.
Enter the nine lords of Scotland, with their nine pages, Gloster, Sussex, King Edward in his suit of Glasse, Queen Elinor, Queen mother, the King and Queen under a canopy.

sp.speaker: Jong.
sp.l: Nobles of Scotland, we thank you all,
For this days gentle princely service done,
To Edward England's King and Scotland's lord:
Our coronations due solemnity ,
Is ended with applause of all estates.
Now then let us appose and rest us here,
But specially we thank you gentle lords,
That you so well have governed your griefs,
As being grown unto a age all ●arre,
You choose King Edward by your messengers,
To calm, to qualify, and to compound:
Thank Britain's strife of Scotland's climbing peers.
I have no doubt fair lords but you well wot,
How factions waste the richest commonwealth,
And discord spoils the seats of mighty Kings.
The baron's wars, a tragic wicked war,
Nobles how hath it shaken England's strength?
Industriously it seems to me you have,
Loyally ventured to prevent this shock,
For which sith you have chosen me your judge,
My lord, will you stand to what I shall award?

sp.speaker: Baliol.
sp.l: Victorious Edward, to whom the Scottish Kings
Owe homage as their lord and sovereign,
Amongst us nine, is but one lawful King:
but might we all be judges in the case,
Then should in Scotland be nine Kings at once,
And this contention never set or limited,
To stay these jars we jointly make appeal,
To thy imperial throne, who knows our claims,
We stand not on our titles before your grace,
But do submit ourselves to your award,
And whom your majesty shall name to be our King,
To him we'll yield obedience as a King,
Thus willingly, and of their own accord,
Doth Scotland make great England's King their judge.

sp.speaker: Lorg.
sp.l: Then nobles since you all agree in one,
That for a crown so disagree in all,
Since what I do shall rest irrevocable,
And lovely England to thy lovely Queen,
Lovely Queen Elinor, unto her turn thy eye,
Whose honour cannot but love thee well,
Hold up your hands in sight, with general voice,
That are content to stand to our award.
sp.stage: They all hold up their hands, and say he shall.
sp.l: Deliver me the golden diadem.
Lo here I hold the goal for which ye strived,
And here behold my worthy men at arms,
For chivalry and worthy wisdom's praise,
Worthy each one to wear a diadem,
Expect my doom, as erst at I da hills,
The goddesses divine waited the award,
Of Danae's son: Balliol stand farthest forth,
Balliol behold I give thee the Scottish crown,
Wear it with heart and with thankfulness:
Sound trumpets, and say all after me,
God save King Balliol the Scottish King.
sp.stage: The trumpets sounds, all cry aloud, God save King Baliol the Scottish King.
sp.l: Thus lords though you require no reason why,
According to the conscience in the cause,
I make John Balliol your anointed King:
honour and love him as behooves him best,
That is in peace of Scotland's crown possessed.

sp.speaker: Baliol.
sp.l: Thanks royal England for thy honour done,
This justice that hath calmed our civil strife:
Shall now be ceased with honourable love,
So moved of remorse and pity,
We will erect a college of my name,
In Oxford will I build for memory,
Of Balliol's bounty and his gratitude:
And let me happy days no longer see,
Then here to England loyal I shall be.

sp.speaker: Elinor.
sp.l: Now brave John Balliol lord of Gallaway,
And King of Scots shine with thy golden head,
Shake thy spears in honour of his name,
Under whose royalty thou wearest the same.
The welkin spangled through with golden spots,
Reflects no finer in a frosty night,
Then lovely Longshanks in his Elinor's eye:
So Ned thy Nell in every part of thee,
Thy person's guarded with a troop of Queens,
And every Queen as brave as Elinor,
Give glory to these glorious crystal quarries,
Where every robe an object entertains,
Of rich device and princely majesty.
Thus like Narcissus diving in the deep,
I die in honour and in England's arms:
And if I drown, it is in my delight.
Whose company is chiefest life in death,
From forth whose coral lips I suck the sweet,
Wherewith are dainty Cupid's candles made,
Then live or die brave Ned, or sink or swim,
An earthly bliss it is to look on him,
On thee sweet Ned, it shall become thy Nell,
Bounteous to be unto the beauteous,
o'er pry the palms sweet fountains of my bliss;
And I will stand on tiptoe for a kiss.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: He had no thought of any gentle heart,
That would not seize desire for such desert,
If any heavenly joy in women be,
Sweet of all sweets, sweet Nell it is in thee.
Now lords along by this the Earl of Marche,
Lord Mortimor o'er Cambria's mountain tops,
Hath ranged his men, and feels Lluellen's mind,
To which confines that we● in wasting be,
Our solemn service of coronation past,
We will amain to back our friends at need,
And into to Wales our men at arms shall march,
And we with them in person foot by foot.
Brother of Scotland, you shall to your home,
And live in honour there fair England friend.
And thou sweet Nell Queen of King Edward's heart.
Shall now come lesser at thy dainty love,
And at coronation meet thy loving peers,
When storms are past, and we have cooled the rage
Of these rebellious Welshmen that contend,
'Gainst England's majesty, and Edward's crown.
Sound trumpets heralds lead the train along,
This be King Edward's feast and holly day.
sp.stage: Enter the maris of London from church, and music before her.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Glocester, who may this be, a bride or what?
I pray ye Joan go see,
And know the reason of the harmony.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Good woman let it not ostend you any whit,
For to deliver unto me the cause,
That in this unusual kind of sort,
You pass the streets with music so.

sp.speaker: Maris.
sp.l: Mistress or madam whate'er you be,
wot you I am the mayor of London's wife,
Who for I have been delivered of a son,
Having not these dozen years had any before,
Now in my husband's year of mayoralty,
Bringing him a goodly boy,
I pass unto my house a maiden bride,
Which private pleasure touching godliness,
Shall hear no way I hope offend the good.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You hope so gentle mistress, do you indeed!
But do not make it parcel of your creed.

sp.speaker: Maris.
sp.l: Alas I am undone, it is the Queen,
The proudest Queen that ever England knew.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Come Gloster, let's to the court and revel there.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: Soft is it not Meredith I behold?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: All good, all friends: Meredith see the man,
Must make us great, and raise Lluellen's head:
Fight thou Lluellen for thy friend and thee.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Fight maugre fortune strong our battles strong,
And bear thy foes before thy pointed lance

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: Not too much prowess good my lord at once.
Some talk of policy another while.

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.l: How comes my li●s hurt at this assault?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Hurt for our good, Meredith make account,
Sir David's wit is full of good device,
And kindly will perform what he pretends.

sp.speaker: David
sp.l: Enough of this my lord at once,
What will you that I hold the King in hand,
Or what shall I especially advise,
Sitting in counsel with the English lords,
That so my counsel may avail my friends?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: David if thou wilt best for me device,
Advise my love be rendered to my hand:
tell them the chains that Mulciber erst made,
To tie Prometheus' limbs to Caucasus,
Nor furies fangs shall hold me long from her,
But I will have her from the usurper's tent,
My beauteous Elinor: if ought in this,
If in this case thy wit may boot thy friends,
Express it then in this, in nothing else.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: I there's a card that puts us to our trump,
For might I see the star of Leister's loins,
It were enough to darken and obscure,
This Edward's glory, fortune, and his pride:
First hereof can I put you out of doubt,
Lord Mortimor of the King hath her in charge,
And honourably entreats your Elinor,
Some thinks he prays Lluellen were in heaven,
And thereby hopes to coach his love on earth.

sp.speaker: Lluel
sp.l: No, where Lluellen mounts, there Ellen flies
Unspeakable are my thoughts for her,
She is not from me in death to be divorced.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: Go to, it shall be so, so shall it be,
Edward is full resolved of thy faith,
So are the English lords and barons all:
Then what may let thee to intrude on them,
Some new found stratagem to feel their wit,
It is enough: Meredith take my weapons,
I am your prisoner, say so at the least,
Go hence, and when you parley on the walls,
Make show of monstrous tyranny you intend,
To execute on me, as on the man,
That shamefully rebels 'gainst kin and kind:
And lea● thou have thy love, and make thy kind:
With such conditions as shall best concern,
David must die say thou a shameful death,
Edward perhaps with ruth and pity moved,
Will in exchange yield Elinor to thee,
And thou by me shalt gain thy hearts desire.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Sweetly advised David, thou blessest me,
my brother David lengthener of my life,
Friends gratulate to me my joyful hopes.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Why barons, suffer ye our foes to breathe?
Assault, assault, and charge them all amain,
They fear, they fly, they faint, they fight in vain,
But where is gentle David in his De●?
Loath were length but good should him betide.
sp.stage: On the walls enter Longshanks, Sussex, Mortimor, David the friar, Meredith holding David by the collar, with a dagger in his hand.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Where is the proud disturber of our state?
Traitor to Wales, and to his sovereign.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Usurper here I am, what dost thou cra●e.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Welshman allegiance which thou owest thy King.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Traitor, no King, that seeks thy country's sack,
The famous runagate of Christendom.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Ambitious rebel, knowest thou what I am,
How great. how famous, and how fortunate,
And dar'st thou carry arms against me here,
Even when thou shouldst do reverence at my feet?
Yea feared and honoured in the farthest parts,
Hath Edward been, thy noble Henry's son,
Traitor, this sword unsheathed hath shined oft,
With reeking in the blood of Sarazens,
When like to Perseus on his winged steed,
Brandishing bright the blood of adamant,
That aged Saturn gave fair Maia's son,
Conflicting though with Gorgon in the vale,
Setting before the gates of Nazareth,
my horse's hooves I stained in pagan's gore,
Sending whole countries of heathen souls,
To Pluto's house: this sword, this thirsty sword,
Aims at thy head, and shall I hope ere long,
Gage and divide thy bowels and thy bulk,
Disloyal villain thou, and what is more.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Why Longshanks, thinkst thou I will be scared with words?
No, didst thou speak in thunder like to Jove,
Or shouldst as Briareus shake at once,
A hundred bloody swords, with bloody hands,
I tell thee Longshanks here he faceth thee,
Whom naught can daunt, no not the stroke of death:
Resolved ye see: but see the chance of war,
Know'st thou a traitor and thou seest his head,
Than Longshanks look this villain in the face:
This rebel he hath wrought his country's wrack,
Base. rascal, had and hated in his kind,
Object of wrath, and subject of revenge.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Lluellen, callest thou this the chance of war?
Bad for us all perdie, but worse for him,
Courage sir David, Kings thou knowest must die,
And noble minds all dastard fear defies.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: Renowned England, star of Edward's globe,
My liefest lord and sweetest sovereign,
Glorious and happy is this chance to me,
To reap this fame and honour in my death,
That I was hewed with soul defiled hands,
For my beloved King and countries good,
And died in grace and favour with my prince:
Seize on me bloody butchers with your paws,
It is but temporal that you can inflict.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Bravely resolved brave soldier by my life.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Hark you sir, I am afeard you will not be so resolved, by that time you know so much as I can show you, here be hot dogs I can tell you, means to have the baiting of you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: Lluellen in the midst of all thy braves,
How wilt thou use thy brother, thou hast ta'en,
Wilt thou let his master ransom him?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: No nor his mistress gallant Mortimor,
With all the gold and silver of the land.

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.l: Ransom this Judas to his father's line,
Ransom this traitor to his brother's life,
No take that earnest penny of thy death,
This touch my lord comes nothing near the mark.
sp.stage: Meredith stabs him into the arms and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: O damned villain hold thy hands,
Ask and have.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: We will nor ask nor have, seest thou these tools?
These be the dogs shall bait him to the death,
And shall by piecemeals tear his cursed flesh,
And in thy sight here shall he hang and pine.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: O villains, traitors, how will I be venged?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: What threats thou Edward,
Desperate minds contemn,
That fury menaceth, see thy words effects.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: O gracious heavens, dissolve me into clay,
This tyranny is more than flesh can bear.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: Bear it brave mind, sith nothing but thy blood,
May satisfy in this extreme estate.

sp.speaker: Sussex.
sp.l: My lord it is in vain to threaten them,
They are resolved ye see upon his death.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sussex, his death, they all shall buy it dear,
Offer them any favour for his life,
Pardon, or peace, or ought what is beside:
So love me God, as I regard my friends.
Lluellen let me have thy brother's life,
Even at what rate and ransom thou wilt name.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Edward, King Edward, as thou list be termed,
Thou knowest thou hast my beauteous Elinor,
Produce her forth, to plead for David's life,
she may obtain more than an host of men.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Wilt thou exchange thy prisoner for thy love?

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Talk no more to me, let me see her face.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: Why, will your majesty be all so base,
To stoop to his demands in every thing?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Fetch her at once, good Mortimor be gone.

sp.speaker: Morti
sp.l: I go, but how unwilling heavens doth know,

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.l: A pace Mortimor if thou love thy friend.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: I go for dearer than I leave behind.
sp.stage: Mortimor goes for Elinor, and conducts her in.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: See Sussex how he bleedeth in my eye,
That beareth fortunes shock triumphantly.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Saw haw, mai●er; I have found, I have found.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: What hast thou found friar, ha?

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.l: News my lord, a star from out the sea,
The same is risen, and made a summer's day.
sp.stage: Then Lluellen spieth Elinor and Mortimor, and sayeth thus.
sp.l: What Nell, sweet Nell, do I behold thy face?
Fall heavens, fleet stars, shine Phoebus lamp no more,
This is the planet lends this world her light,
Star of my fortune, this that shineth bright,
Queen of my heart, load star of my delight,
Fair mould of beauty, miracle of fame,
Oh let me die with Elinor in mine arms:
What honour shall I lend thy loyalty,
Or praise unto thy sacred deity.

sp.speaker: Mered.
sp.p: Marry this my lord, if I may give you counsel, sacrifice this tike in her sight, her friend, which being done, one of your soldiers may dip his foul shirt in his blood, so shall you be waited with as many crosses as King Edward.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Good cheer sir David, we shall up anon.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: Die Mortimor, thy life is almost gone.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Sweet prince of Wales, were I within thine arms,
Then should I in peace possess my love,
And heavens open fair their crystal gates,
that I may see the palace or my intent.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Lluellen set try brother free,
Let me have him, thou shalt have Elinor.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Sooth Edward I do prize my Elinor,
Dearer than life, but there belongeth more
To these affairs, than my content in love:
And to be short, if thou wilt have thy man,
Of whom I swear thou thinkest over well,
The safety of Lluellen and his men,
Must be regarded highly in this match,
Say therefore and be short, wilt thou give peace
And pardon to Lluellen and his men.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I will herein have time to be advised.

sp.speaker: Lluel
sp.l: King Edward no, we will admit no pause,
For goes this wretch, this wretch to the pot,
And if Lluellen be pursued so near,
May chance to show thee such a tumbling cast,
As e'er our father, when he thought to scape,
And broke his neck from Julius Caesar's town.

sp.speaker: Sussex.
sp.l: My lord these rebels all are desperate.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: And Mortimor of all most miserable.

sp.speaker: Longsh
sp.l: How say you Welshmen, will you leave your arms,
And be true liegemen unto Edward's crown?

sp.speaker: Al● the soldier
sp.l: If Edward pardon surely what is past,
Upon conditions we are all content.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Belike you will condition with us then.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Special conditions for our safety first,
And for our country Cambria's common good,
T'avoid the fusion of our guilty blood.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Go to, say on.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: First for our followers and ourselves and all,
We ask a pardon in the prince's word,
Then for this lords possession in his love:
But for our country cheer these bones we beg,
And England's promise princely to thy wails,
That none be Cambria's prince to govern us,
but he that is a Welshman born in Wales.
Grant this and swear it on thy knightly sword,
And have thy man, and us, and all in peace.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: Why Cambria Britain's are you so incensed,
Will you deliver me to Edward's hands?

sp.speaker: Sold●.
sp.l: No lord Lluellen we will back for thee,
Thy life, thy love, and golden liberty.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: A truce with honourable conditions ta'en,
Wales happiness, England's glo●, and my bane.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Command retreat be sounded in our camp,
Soldiers I grant at full what you request,
David good cheer, Lluellen open the gates.

sp.speaker: Lluel.
sp.l: The gates are opened, enter thee and thine.

sp.speaker: Da●.
sp.l: The sweetest sun that ere I saw to shine.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Madam, a brabble well begun for thee,
Be thou my guest, and sir Lluellen's love.
Mortimor, a brabble ill began for thee,
A truce with capital conditions ta'en:
A prisoner saved and ransomed with thy life,
Edward my King, my lord and lover dear,
Full little dost thou wot, how this retreat.
As with a sword, hath slain poor Mortimor.
Farewell the flower the gem of beauty's blaze,
Sweet Ellen, miracle of nature's hand,
Fuellen in thy name, but heaven is in thy looks,
Sweet Venus let me saint or devil be,
In that sweet heaven or hell that is in thee,
sp.stage: Enter Jack and the harper getting a standing against the Queen comes in.

The trumpets sound Queen elinor or in her litter borne by four negro Moors jone of acton with her, attended on by the Earl of Glocester, and her four footmen, one having set a ladder to the side de of the litter. She descended and her daughter followeth.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Give me my pantables.
Fie this hot weather how it makes me sweat,
Heigh ho my heart, ah I am passing faint.
Give me my fan that I may cool my face,
Hold, take my mask but see you rumple not,
This wind and dust see how it smolders me,
Some drink good Gloster or I die for drink,
Ah Ned thou hast forgotten thy Nell I see,
That she is thus enforced to follow thee. (Majesty

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.l: This air's distemperature and please your
Noisome through mountains vapours send thick mist,
Unpleasant needs must be to you and your company,
That never was wont to take the air,
Till Flora have perfumed the earth with sweets,
With lilies, roses, mints and eglantine,

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: I tell thee the ground is all too base,
For Elinor to honour with her steps:
Whose footpace when she progressed in the street,
Of Aecon and the fair Jerusalem,
Was naught but costly arras points:
Fair I land tapestry and azured silk,
My milk white steed treading on cloth of ray,
And trampling proudly under the feet,
Choice of our English woollen drapery.
This climate or clowring with black congealed clouds,
That takes their swelling from the marish soil,
Fraught with infectious frogs and rvistie damps,
Is far unworthy to be once embalmed:
With redolence of this refreshing breath:
That sweetens where it lights as do the flames,
And holy fires of Vesta's sacrifice. spring,

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Whose pleasant fields new planted with the
Make Thamesis to mount above the banks,
And like a wanton walloing up and down:
On Flora's beds and napees silver down.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And waleses for me madam while you are here,
No climate good unless your grace be near,
would Wales had ought could please you half so well,
Or any precious thing in Gloucester's gift,
Whereof your ladyship would challenge me.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Well said my lord 'tis as my mother says,
You men have learned to woe a thousand ways.

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.l: O madam had I learned against my need,
Of all those ways to woo one way to speed,
My cunning then had been my fortune's guide.

sp.speaker: Q. Eli.
sp.l: Faith Joan I think thou must be Gloucester's bride,
Good Earl how near he steps unto her side,
So soon this eye these younglings had espied,
I'll tell thee girl when I was fair and young:
I found such honey in sweet Edward's tongue,
As I could never spend one idle walk,
But Ned and I would piece it out with talk.
So you my lord when you have got your Joan,
No matter let Queen mother be alone.
Old Nell is mother now and grandmother may,
The greenest grass doth droop and turn to hay,
Woo one kind clerk, good Gloster love thy Joan,
Her heart is thine, her eyes is not her own.

sp.speaker: Gl
sp.l: This comfort madam that your grace doth give
Binds me in double duty whilst I live,
Would god King Edward see and say no less.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Gloster I warrant thee upon my life,
My King vouchsafes his daughter for thy wife,
Sweet Ned hath not forgotten since he did woo,
The gall of love and all that longs thereto.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: Why was your grace so coy to one so kind?

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli
sp.l: Kind Gloster so methinks in deed,
It seems he loves his wife no more than needs,
That sends for us in all the speedy haste,
Knowing his Queen to be so great with child,
And make me leave my princely pleasant seats,
To come into his ruder part of Wales.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: His highness hath some secret reason why,
He wisheth you to move from England's pleasant courts
the Welshmen have of long time suitors been,
That when the war of rebels sorts an end:
None might be prince and ruler over them,
But such a one as was their countryman,
Which sure I think his grace hath granted them.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: So then it is King Edward's policy,
To have his son, for sooth son i● be,
A Welshman, well Welshman it liketh me,
And ●re he comes.
sp.stage: Enter Edward Longshanks and his lords, to the Queen and her footmen.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Nell, welcome into Wales,
How fares my Elinor?

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Near worse, beshrew their hearts 'tis long on.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Heart's sweet Nell, shrew no hearts,
Where such sweet saints do dwell

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Nay then I see I have my dream, I pray let go,
You will not will you whether I will or no?
You are disposed to move me.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Say any thing but so:
Once Nell thou gavest me this.

sp.speaker: Queen Eli.
sp.l: I pray let go, ye are disposed I think.

sp.speaker: Long
sp.l: I madam very well

sp.speaker: Qu. El.
sp.l: Let go and be naught I say.

sp.speaker: Longsh
sp.l: What ails my Nell?

sp.speaker: Queen Eli.
sp.l: Aye me, what sudden fits is this I prove;
What grief, what pine lung pain, like youngmen's love,
That makes me madding tun thus to and fro●?

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: What, melancholy Nell?

sp.speaker: Queen Eli.
sp.l: My lord pray let me go.
Give me sweetwater, why how hot it is?

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.l: These be the fits, trouble men's wits.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Joan ask thy beauteous mistress how she doth.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: How fares your majesty?

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Joan aggrieved at the heart and angered worse,
Because I came not right in,
I think the King comes purposely to spite me,
My finger itch till I have had my will,
Proud Edward call in thy Elinor be still,
It will not be, nor rest I anywhere :
Till I have set it soundly on his ear.

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Is that the matter then let me alone.

sp.speaker: Qu. Elin.
sp.l: Fie how I fret with grief.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Come hither Joan, knowest thou what ails my Queen?

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Not I my lord, she longs I think to give your grace a box on there.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Nay wench if that be as we'll ear it well,
What all a mort how doth my dainty Nell?
Look up sweet love, unkind, not kiss me once?
That may not be.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: My lord I think you do it for the nonce.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sweet heart one kiss.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: For god's sake let me go.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Sweet heart a kiss.

sp.speaker: Queen Eli.
sp.l: What, whether I will or no? you will not leave? let be I say?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: I must be better chid.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli
sp.l: No will? take that then lusty lord, sir leave when you are bid.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: Why so this chare is charred.

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.l: A good one by the rood,

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: No force no harm.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: No harm that doth my Elinor any good.
Learn lords 'gainst you be married men to bow to women's yoke:
And sturdy though you be you may not stir for every stroke:
Now my sweet Nell how doth my Queen?

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: She vaunts that mighty England hath felt her fist:
taken a blow basely at Elinor's hand,
And vaunt she may good leave being cursed and coy,
Lack nothing Nell whilst thou hast brought thy lord a lovely boy.

sp.speaker: Veniacion
sp.l: I am sick good Katherina I pray thee beat hand.

sp.speaker: Kath. Spain.
sp.l: This sickness I hope will bring King Edward a jolly boy.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.p: And Katherin who brings me that news shall not go empty handed.

sp.speaker: Mortimor.
sp.l: Farewell Lluellen with thy loving Nell.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Godamercy Mortimor and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.l: Farewell and be hanged half Sinon's sapons brood

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Good words sir rice wrongs have best remedy,
So taken with time patience and policy.
But where is the friar who can tell?
That can I master very well,
And say i'faith what hath befell:
Must we at once to heaven or hell?

sp.speaker: Elinor.
sp.l: To heaven friar, friar no fie,
Such heavy souls mount not so high.

sp.speaker: Friar lies down.
sp.l: Then friar lie thee down and die.
And if any ask the reason why,
Answer and say thou canst not tell,
Unless because thou must to hell.

sp.speaker: Eli
sp.l: No friar because thou didst rebel,
Gentle sir rice ring out thy knel.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.p:
And maddock toll thy passing bell. So there lies a straw, and now to the law masters and friends, naked came we in to the world naked are we
turned out of the good towns into the wilderness, let me say mass, methinks we are a handsome commonwealth, a handful of good-fellows, set a sunning to dog on our own discretion, what say you sir? we are enough to keep a passage, will you be ruled by me? we'll get the next day from Brecknock the book of Robin hood, the friar he shall instruct us in his cause and we'll even here fare and well since the King hath put us amongst the discarding cards, and as it were turned us with deuces and trays out of the deck, every man take his standing on Mannocke deny and wander like irregulers up and down the wilderness, I'll be master of misrule, I'll be Robin hood that once, cousin rice thou shalt be little John, and hers friar David as fit as a die for friar Tucke, now my sweet Nell if you will make up the mess with a good heart for maid Marian and do well with Lluellen under the green wood trees, with as good a will as in the good towns, why plena est curia.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: My sweetest love and this my infract fortune could never vaunt har sovereignty, and shouldst thou pass the ford of Phlegeton, or with Leander win the Hellispont in deserts, Oenophrius ever dwell, or build thy bower on Aetna's fiery tops, thy Nell would follow thee and keep with thee, thy Nell would feed with thee and sleep with thee.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: O cupido quantus quantus.

sp.speaker: Mere.
sp.p: Bravely resolved madam and t●n what rests my lord robin but we will live and die together like chamber Britain's, Robin hood, little John, friar Tucke, and maid Marian.

sp.speaker: Llue.
sp.p: There rests nothing now cousin but that I sell my chain to set us all in green and we'll all play the pioneers to make us a cave and cabin for all weathers.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.p: My sweet Lluellen though this sweet be gall, patience doth conquer me by out suffering all.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Now Mannock deny I hold thee a penny,
Thou shalt have neither sheep nor goat:
but friar David, will fleeces his coat,
Where ever lack my novice jet.
All is fish with him that comes to net,
David this year thou payest no debt.

sp.speaker: Mortimor.
sp.l: Why f●er is it so plain in deed,
Lluellen art thou flatly so resolved.
To roust it out and roust so near the King:
What shall we have a passage kept in Wales:
For men at arms and knights adventurous?
By cock sir rice I see no reason why,
Young Mortimor should make one among:
And play high, parton Mannock dying here,
For love of his beloved Elinor:
His Elinor where she this I wot,
The bitter Northern wind upon the plains:
The damps that rise from out the quickly plots:
Nor influence of contagious air should touch,
But she should court yet with the proudest dames,
Rich in attire and sumptuous in her fare.
And take her ease in beds of safest down,
Why Mortimor may not thy offers move,
And win sweet E● from Lluellen's love,
Why pleasant gold and gentle eloquence,
Have beset the chastest nymphs the fairest dames,
And vaunts of words, delights of wealth and ease,
Have made a nun 10 yield Lluellen's,
Being set to see the last of desperate chance,
Why should so fair a star stand in a vale?
And not be seen to sparkle in the sky,
It is enough Jove change his glittering robes:
To see Mennosyne and the flies
Masters have altar gentle Robinhood,
You are not so well accompanied I hope:
but if a potter come to play his part,
You'll give him stripes or welcome good or worse:
Go Mortimor and make their love holidays,
The King will take a common 'scuse of thee,
And who hath more men to attend then Mortimor.
sp.stage: Enter Lluellen, Meredith, Friar, Elinor, and their train.
They are all clad in green etc. sing etc. Blithe and bonny, the song ended Lluellen speaketh.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Why so, I see my mates of old,
All were not lies that bedlams told:
Of Robin hood and little John,
Friar Tucke and maid Marian.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: I for sooth master.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: How well they couched in forest green,
Frolic and lively with oaten teen:
And spent their day in game and glee,
Lluellen do seek if ought please thee,
Nor though thy foot be out of town,
Let thine look black on Edward's crown.
Nor think this green is not so gay,
As was the golden rich array:
And if sweet Nell my marrian,
Trust me as I am gentle man:
Thou art as fine in this at tire:
As fine and fit to my desire,
As when of Leister's hall and bower,
Thou wert the rose and sweetest flowers
How sayest thou friar say I well?
For any thing becomes my Nell.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Never made man of a woman born,
A bullock's tail a blowing horn,
Nor can an ass's hide disguise,
a lion if he ramp and rise.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: My lord, the friar is wondrous wise.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Believe him for he tells no lies,
But what doth little John devise?

sp.speaker: Meredith.
sp.l: That robin hood beware of spies,
An aged saying and a true,
Black will take no other hue.
He that of old hath been thy toe:
Will die but will continue so.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: O masters, whither shall we, doth any living creature know?

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Rice and I will walk the round,
Friar see about the ground.
And spoil what pray is to be found,
My love I leave within in trust,
Because I know thy dealing lust:
Come potter come and welcome to,
Fare as we fare and do as we do.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Nell adieu we go for news,
A little serves the friar's lust,
When nolens volens fast I must,
Master at all that you refuse.

sp.speaker: Mortimor.
sp.l: Such a porter would I choose,
When I mean to blind a skull.
While Robin walk with little Jo●,
The friar will lick his marrian.
So will the porter if he can.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Now friar sith your lord is gone,
And you and I are left alone,
What can the friar do or say,
To pass the weary time away?
Weary God wot poor wench to thee,
That never thought these days to see.

sp.speaker: Mortimor.
sp.l: Bre●ke heart and split mine eyes in twain.
Never let me hear those words again.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: What can the friar do or sal●
To pass the weary time away:
More dare I do then he dare say,
Because he doubts to have away.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Do somewhat friar say or sing,
That may to sorrows so lace bring,
And I meanwhile will garlands make,

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: O Mortimor were it for thy sake,
A garland were the happiest stake:
That ever this hand unhappy drew.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Mistress shall I tell you true,
I have a song I learned it long ago,
I wot not whether you'll like it well or ill,
'Tis short and sweet but somewhat brolde before.
Once let me sing it and I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: What friar will you so indeed,
Agrees it somewhat with your need?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Why mistress shall I sing my creed,

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: That's fitter of the two at need.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: O wench how mayst thou hope to speed?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: O mistress out it goes.
Look what comes next the friar throes.
sp.stage: The friar sits along and sings.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: Such a sitting whoever saw,
An eagle's bird of a Jack daw.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: So sir is this all?

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: Sweet heart here's no more.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: How now good fellow more indeed,
By one then was before.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: How now the devil in steed of a ditty.

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: Friar a ditty come late from the city.
To ask some pity of this lass so pretty:
Some pity sweet mistress I pray you.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: How now friar where are we now and you play not the man?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Friend Copes mate, you that come late from the city,
To ask some pity of this lass so pretty,
In likeness of a doleful ditty,
Hang me if I do not pay ye.

sp.speaker: Mortimor.
sp.l: O friar you grow choleric, well you'll
Have no man to court your mislers but yourself,
On my word I'll take you down a bottom hole,

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Ye talk, ye talk child.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: 'Tis well potter you fight in a good quarrel,

sp.speaker: Meredith.
sp.l: Mas this blade will hold let see me then friar.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.p: Mine's for mine own turn 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 his tools, rise and let's to it, b● 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 you love me, I scorn the odds I can tell you, ●ee fair play and you be gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.p: Marry shall we friar, let us see, be their staves of a length good, so now let us deem of the matter friar and potter without more clatter I have cast your water, and see as deep into your desire, as he that had dived every day into your bosom, oh friar will nothing serve your turn but larks.
sp.l: Are such five birds for such course clerks,
None but my Marian can serve your turn.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Cast water, for the house will burn.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: O mistress mistress flesh is frail,
Ware when the sign is in the tail,
Mighty is love and doth prevail:

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Therefore friar shalt thou not fail,
But mightily your foe assail:
And thrash this potter with thy flail,
And potter never rave nor rail,
Not ask questions what I ail:
But take this tool and do not quail,
but thrash this friars russet coat:
And make him sing a dastards note,
And cry peccaus miserere David,
In am● ama●: goc to.

sp.speaker: Mortimor.
sp.l: Strike, strike.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Strike potter be thou lief or loath,
And if you'll not strike I'll strike for both.

sp.speaker: Potter strikes.
sp.l: He must needs go that the devil drives
Then friar beware of other men's wives.

sp.speaker: Friar strikes.
sp.l: I wish master proud potter the devil have my soul:
But I'll. make my flail circumscribe your noll.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Why so, now it cottons, now the game begins.
One knave currieth another for his sins.

sp.speaker: Friar kneels.
sp.l: O master short en my offences in mine eyes.
If this crucifige do not suffice,
Send me to heaven in a hempen sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Friar kneels.
sp.l: O masters masters let this be warning:
The friar hath infected me with his learning.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.l: Villain's do not touch the forbidden hair now to delude, or to dishonour me.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: O master, quae nagata sunt grata sunt.

sp.speaker: Lluellen.
sp.p: Rice every day thus shall it be, we'll have a thrashing set among the friars, and he that of these challengers lays on slowest load, be thou at hand rice to gore him with thy good.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: A potter Potter the friar may rue,
That ever this day this our quarrel he knew:
My pate addle, mine arms black and blue.

sp.speaker: Potter.
sp.l: Ah friar who may his fate's force eschew,
I think friar you are prettily schooled,

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: And I think the potter is handsomely cold,

sp.speaker: Morti.
sp.l: No Martimor here that eternal fire,
That burns and ha●s with brands of hot desire●
Why Martimor, why doest thou not discover,
Thyself her knight her liegeman and her lover?
sp.stage: Enter John Balliol, King of Scots with his train.
sp.l: Lords of Albana, and my peers in France.
Since Balliol is invested in his rights,
And wears the royal Scottish diadem,
Time is to rouse him that the world may wot,
Scotland disdains to carry England's yoke.
Therefore my friend thus put in readiness,
Why slack we time to greet the English King?
Wi● resolute message to let him know our minds,
Lord Versses though thy faith and oath be ta'en,
To follow Balliol's arms for Scotland's right,
Yet is thy heart to England's honour knit,
Therefore in spite of England and thyself,
Bear thou defiance proudly to thy King,
Tell him 〈◊〉 finds heart and hope,
To shake of England's tyranny be time,
To rescue Scotland's honour with his sword,
Lord Bruce see cast about Versses' neck,
A strangling halter that he mind his ha●t.
How farest thou Versses wilt thou do this message?

sp.speaker: Versses.
sp.l: Although no common post, yet for my King
I will to England maugre England's might,
And do mine errand boldly as becomes,
Albeit I honour English Edward's name,
And hold this slavish contemnment to scorn.

sp.speaker: Balioll.
sp.l: Then hie away as swift as swallow flies,
And meet ●e on our roads on England's ground,
We there think of thy message and thy 〈◊〉.
sp.stage: Enter King Edward Longshanks, Edmund Duke of Lancaster, Gloster, Sussex, David, Crespall booted from Northam.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Now have I leisure lords to bid you welcome into Wales.
Welcome sweet Edmund to christen thy young nephew
And welcome Cressingham, give me thy hand,
But Sussex what became of Mortimor?
We have not seen the man this many a day.

sp.speaker: Sussex.
sp.l: Before your highness rid from hence to Northam.
Sir Roger was a suitor to your grace,
Touching fair Elinor Lluellen's love,
And so belike denied with discontent,
'A discontinues from your royal presence.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Why Sussex said we not for Elinor,
So she would leave whom she had loved too long,
She might have favour with my Queen and me,
But man, her 〈◊〉 about her fortune mounts,
And that's a cause she ●ailes in her accounts.
But go with me my lord of Lancaster,
We will go see my beauteous lovely Queen,
That hath enriched me with a goodly boy.
sp.stage: King Edward, Edmund, and Gloster, goes into the the Queen's chamber, the Queen's tent opens, she is discovered in her bed, attended by Mary Duchess of Lancaster jone of Acon ●er daughter and the Queen dandles 〈◊〉 his young son.
sp.p: Longsh ladies by your leave, how doth my Nell, mine own ●ny love, my life, my heart, my dear, my dove, my Queen, my wife.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 N● art thou come, sweet Ned welcome my joy.
Thy Nell presents thee with a lovely boy.
Kiss him, and christen him after thine own name.
Hey ho whom do I see, my lord of Lancaster, welcome heartily.

sp.speaker: Lancaster.
sp.l: I thank your grace, sweet Nell well met withal.

sp.speaker: Q. Eli.
sp.l: Brother Emund hers a kinsman of yours you must need, be acquainted.

sp.speaker: Edmund
sp.l: A goodly boy God bless him, give me your hand sir, you are welcome into Wales.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Brother there's a fist I warrant you will hold
Mace as f●t as ever did father or grandfather before him.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: But ●el in now leapt in lily bands,
How with my Queen, my lovely boy it stands:
After thy journey and these child bed pains.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Sick mine own Ned thy Nell for thy company:
That lured her with thy lies all so far,
To follow thee unwieldy in thy war,
But I forgive thee Ned my limbs' delight:
So thy young son thou see be bravely dight,
And in Carnarvan christened royally.
Sweet love let him be leapt most curiously,
He is thine own, as true as he is thine,
Take order then that he be passing fine.

sp.speaker: Longsh
sp.l: My lovely lady let that care be less,
For my young son the country will I feast:
And have him born as bravely to the font;
As ever yet King's son to christening went.
Lack thou no precious thing to comfort thee,
De rear then England's diadem unto me.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Thanks gentle lord, nurse rock the cradle, fie:
The King so near, and here the boy to cri●?
Joan take him up and sing a lullaby.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: 'Tis well believe me wench godamercy i●,

sp.speaker: Edmund.
sp.l: Sl●e learns my lord to ●ull a young one of her own.

sp.speaker: Qu. Eli.
sp.l: Give me some drink.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Drink nectar my sweet Nell,
worthy for seat in heaven with Jove to dwell.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Gramercis Ned, now well remembered yet,
I have a suit sweet lord, but you must not deny it,
Whereas my lord of Gloster, good Clare mine host, my guide,
Good Ned let Joan of Acon be his bride,
Assure yourself that they are thoroughly wooed.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: God send the King be taken in the mood,
Than niece 'tis like that you shall have a husband,
Come hither Gloster hold give her thy hand,
Take her, sole daughter to the Queen of England.
For news he brought Nell of my young son,
I promised him as much as I have done.
sp.stage: Gloster and Jone hand in hand.
sp.l: We humbly thank your majesty.

sp.speaker: Edmund.
sp.l: Much joy may them betide,
A gallant bridegroom and a princely bride.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Now say sweet Queen what doth my lady crave?
Tell me what name shall this young Welshman have,
Born prince of Wales by Cambria's full consent.

sp.speaker: Eli.
sp.l: Edward the name, that doth me well content,

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Then Edward of Carnarvan shall he be,
And prince of Wales christened in royalty.

sp.speaker: D. Edmund
sp.l: My lord I think the Queen would take a nap,

sp.speaker: Ione.
sp.l: Nurse take the child and hold in your lap,

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: Farewell good Joan be careful of my Queen.
Sleepe Nell, the fairest swan mine eyes have seen.

sp.speaker: D. Edmund.
sp.l: I had forgot-to ask your majesty.
How do you with the abbeys here in Wales,

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: As Kings with rebels Mun, our right prevails,
We have good robin hood and little John,
the friar and the good maid; marrian.
Why our Lluellen is a mighty man.

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.l: Trust me my lord, methinks 'twere very good
That some good fellows went and scoured the wood,
And take in hand to cudgel Robin hood.
I think the friar for all his lusty looks,
Nor robin rule with their gleams and hooks,
But would be quickly driven to the nooks.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: I can assure your highness what I know,
The false Lluellen will not run nor go
Or give an inch of ground come man for man,
Nor that proud rebel called little John,
To him that wields the massiest sword of England,

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.l: Welshman, how wilt thou that we understand,
But for Lluellen, David I deny,
England hath men will make Lluellen fly,
Maugre his beard and hide him in a hole,
Weary of England's dints and manly dole.

sp.speaker: D. Edm.
sp.l: Gloster, grow not so hot in England's right,
That paints his honour out in every sight.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.l: By Gis fair lords ere many days be passed,
England shall give this robin hood his breakfast.
David, be secret friend to that I say,
And if I use thy skill thou knowest the way.
Where this proud robin and his yeomen roam.

sp.speaker: David.
sp.l: I do my lord and blindfold thither can I run.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
sp.l: David enough, as I am a gentleman,
I'll have one merry flirt with little John,
And Robin hood, and his maid Marian,
Be thou my counsel and my company,
And thou mayst England's resolution see.
sp.stage: Enter Sussex before the four barons of Wales.

sp.speaker: Sussex.
sp.p:
May it please your majesty, here are 4. good squires of the cantréds where they do dwell, come in the name of the whole country to gratulate unto your
highness all your good fortunes, and by me offer their most humble service to your young son their prince, whom they most heartily beseech God to bless with long life and honour.

sp.speaker: Longsh.
